awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Exploring the 3D structure organization of genomes
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made to the University of Southern California to develop methods for studying the 3D spatial organization of genomes. Knowing 3D genome structures and the spatial distributions of individual genes for various cell states would drastically change our view of the genome landscape. However, the 3D structures of genomes have yet to be determined. With the rapid accumulation of diverse genomic, epigenomic, and imaging data, the time has come to tackle this challenge by combining all available sources of information. This career-development plan proposes novel approaches to model the 3D structures of genomes by combining various large-scale data sources, by identifying important functional units in the 3D structures, and by characterizing structural elements in genome architectures through image analysis. The modeling of the higher-order genome structures will provide deep insights into gene regulation, and establish the missing link between genomics, functional genomics and structural biology. The 3D genome structure is highly variable, even among cells from an isogenic sample and no single structure can accurately describe all spatial properties of the genome. To address this challenge, this research will provide a novel population-based structural modeling approach, which constructs a population of 3D genome structures that are altogether entirely consistent with all available experimental data, including data from imaging and chromosome conformation capture experiments. This research will also provide novel tools for establishing links between spatial and functional organizations of genomes and will provide the atlases of functional spatial units in various genomes under different conditions. Finally this research will develop novel methods for pattern recognition in imaging of nuclei. A significant amount of effort is devoted to developing software and a web database for integrative 3D genome modeling (project URL: http://www.cmb.usc.edu/people/alber/3D-genome.html).

This project has a strong commitment to directly involve students at all levels by building a strong training program in computational structural biology at USC. This research will be incorporated into an undergraduate course in structural bioinformatics as well as training of graduate students and post-doc fellows. Discussion forums will be held for minority high school and undergraduate students encouraging their pursuing higher education.

por.por_cntn:
The completion of the human genome sequence marks one of the most important accomplishments in biology. However, the genome has levels of complexity that go far beyond its linear sequences. Knowledge about the detailed three-dimensional (3D) folding of genomes helps us gain deep insights into the regulatory mechanisms underlying development, cellular differentiation, and disease progression. However, evidence shows that genome structures are inherently dynamic, with large cell-to-cell variations even among cells of the same type and under the same condition. Thus, no single structure can accurately describe all spatial properties of the genome in a particular cell type. Rather, a successful model is one that constructs a population of 3D genome structures that is entirely consistent with all available data from experiment. 

In this proposal, we have addressed this challenge and developed novel computational methods to determine populations of 3D genome structures entirely consistent with experimental data and to establish structure-function maps of the dynamic genome. We achieved the following objectives: (1) We developed a novel, data-driven population-based modeling approach to characterize 3D genome structures from experimental data. We pioneered a probabilistic approach and provided a software package (called PGS) for the generation of a population of distinct diploid 3D genome structures entirely consistent with all the chromatin-chromatin interaction probabilities from Hi-C experiments. The method deconvolutes ensemble data into a population of single-cell genome structures, which recapitulate all input information. Because the method allows for different conformational states between cells, it can describe an unbiased representation of genome structure variability. The analysis of these models yielded new insights into the causes and the functional properties of the genome's organization in space and time. We also expanded our method to integrate a variety of complementary data, including data from lamin B1 DamID experiments.  We performed a detailed comparative analysis of genome structures from a variety of cell types and organism, including human GM12878 and fibroblast cells, mouse cardiomyocytes, neutrophils and progenitor cells as well as cells from Drosophila Melanogaster embryos. Our analysis provided a deeper understanding of genome functions and mechanistic insights into how the nucleus is spatially organized and functions.  (2) We designed a strategy to identify functional spatial units within the population of genome structures. Our method comprehensively identifies an atlas of stable chromatin clusters that each occurs frequently across a population of genome structures. The atlas of functional spatial units links genome conformations to a variety of nuclear processes (transcription, translocation, DNA replication, etc.), providing a comprehensive picture of the spatial and functional organization of the nucleus. A large number of these clusters are enriched in binding of specific regulatory factors and are therefore defined as 'Regulatory Communities.' We showed that the regulatory communities differ substantially from cell to cell, indicating that heterogeneity of gene expression between cells is impacted by genome structural variations.  (3) We developed imaging analysis tools to facilitate the quantitative analysis of the spatial genome organization. We developed a software package for structural pattern mining in cryo tomography maps of nuclei. Specifically, we developed a software package for large-scale efficient classification of subtomograms to detect recurrent structural features. (4) Software development: We have published a series of freely available software packages for 3D genome structure determination and analysis as well as image analysis tools. These resources will benefit other investigators and accelerate research in this field.
